Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-RESTOR Novel Ceramic Glass Composites for Improved Electrical Energy Storage
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ideal solution to large-scale energy storage will allow fast storage and release of energy in a device such as a reusable electrical storage medium. The proposed work is focused on realizing high energy density storage in a capacitor made with a ceramic of high dielectric constant. The PIs propose a novel approach, which is the combination of a ferroelectric nanopowder and a low melting and alkali-free glass to improve on current electrochemical capacitors. The main advantage of a ceramic capacitor over conventional capacitors is the fast discharge rate. A device resulting from this work could lead to a new method for storing intermittently available electrical energy from sources such as solar cells and wind turbines. A goal of this project is to discover novel materials capable of high energy density storage in capacitors. Such materials will both withstand high electric fields (~1 MV/cm) and possess an extremely high dielectric constant (~100,000). To realize this in prototype test devices, and in a commercially viable way, is a complicated problem of ceramic science and glass engineering. In this project, improvements in electrical energy density will be achieved by storing energy capacitively using a composite of a ferroelectric nanopowder (e.g., [Ba(Ti0:8Zr0:2)O3]0.80-[(Ba0:7Ca0:3)TiO3]0.20 and/or Pb[(Fe1/2Nb1/2)0.6-(Fe2/3W1/3)0.4)O3]) and low melting, alkali-free glass (e.g., B2O3-SiO2-PbO-BaO-TiO2 or B2O3-SiO2-ZnO-BaO-TiO2). The dielectric constant of the glassy phase can be increased by controlled crystallization after the sealing. The broader impact of the proposed research is to develop a novel approach to energy storage that will potentially find application in many areas including environmental protection, consumer electronics, electric vehicles, and healthcare. Being able to efficiently store large amounts of intermittent renewable energy would be a key step in meeting the nation?s and the world?s demand for energy. In addition, the innovative approach coupled with the coordination of multiple disciplines to study a new concept for renewable energy storage will impact the basic curriculum, i.e., concepts in renewable energy storage will be taught from an engineering perspective in design, fabrication, and data analysis. The PIs will exchange students between the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and the University of Puerto Rico to promote integration between the two different student populations as well as the RPI NSF Center for Nanotechnology and the UPR Institute for Functional Nanomaterials.

The FY 2010 EFRI-RESTOR Topic that supports this project was sponsored by the US National Science Foundation (NSF) directorates for Engineering (ENG), Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS) and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE), and Computer & Information Science and Engineering in collaboration with the US Department of Energy (DOE).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electricity generated from renewable and sustainable energy sources needs energy storage such as dielectric capacitors to make it effective. Additionally personal electronics, electric vehicles, entertainment, and homeland security would also benefit from capacitive energy storage. However, conventional dielectric materials, with their limited energy densities, cannot meet these needs. The dielectric constant and the breakdown strength both contribute to the energy density of a capacitor. The energy density is, in general, directly proportional to the dielectric constant, while it is proportional to the square of dielectric breakdown strength. Furthermore, ferroelectrics, which have high dielectric constants in low electric fields, often exhibit dielectric saturation nullifying the benefits of high electric field. Also materials with high dielectric constant have low dielectric breakdown strength. In order to reduce the dielectric saturation, nano-scale ferroelectric grains are necessary and glassy matrix is desirable to improve the dielectric breakdown strength.

Our program focused on those aspects of nano-composites that are important to the enhancement of energy density. The accomplishments of our research project include the following: 1) evaluated the process innovations that led to the continuous, rapid production of nano-composites via ink-jet printing; 2) elucidated the fundamental changes in electronic, thermal, and electromechanical breakdown mechanisms, 3) modeled the fundamental electrostatic phenomena of polymer-ceramic nano-composites, 4) conducted reliability studies, and 5) extended the concept to design composites with high energy density.    

Lead-free ceramics, barium zirconate-titanate (BZT), barium calcium-titanate (BCT), barium strontium-titanate (BST), and glass mixtures were investigated to improve breakdown fields and energy densities to ~280 kV/cm and ~1.1 J/cm3, respectively. For the BCT and BZT ceramics, the largest energy density was 1.41 and 0.71 J/cm3, respectively, with high dielectric breakdown strength of 150 kV/cm for both. BZT-BCT ceramic compositions showed breakdown fields of ~130–170 kV/cm, energy densities of ~0.84–0.97 J/cm3 and maximum high dielectric constant values of ~5200-8400.

We have demonstrated the scalability of thiol-alkene click polymer dielectrics for application to energy storage devices. The average volumetric energy density of 32 J/cm3 was achieved. For the advancement of polymer-ceramic nano-composites, high dielectric constant nano-particles with controlled size and shape are crucial in order to form uniform dispersions during casting and deposition, and to control the internal field concentration. Using the solvo-thermal growth method various compounds were grown. They include BaTiO3, BaxCa1-xTiO3, BaxCa1-xTixZr1-xO3 and TiO2. Many of the nano-particles were used for dispersion into polymer matrices for nano-composite testing. We have also made composites of polymer and ceramic by grafting polymer coatings onto the ceramic solute particles and increased the dielectric breakdown strength, thus increasing energy storage capability.

Our core-shell polymer-ceramic nano-composite through a grafted method resulted in energy densities in excess of 20 J/cm3. Through interfacial engineering, the incoherent interface between ceramic nanoparticle and polymer matrix was eliminated to improve the breakdown strength by 50% and to achieve energy density in the range of 13-36 J/cm3. Our results demonstrate that these compositions are promising candidates for capacitive energy storage applications. The unique nano-composites arising from this research may offer energy densities up to 50 J/cm3; this could be important for replacing current Pb-acid battery-related technologies. For highly crystalline BZT thin films, under an applied field of 3.0 MV/cm at 300 K, we obtained a energy density of 156 J/cm3.

A core-shell nano-scale mixing technique was applied to fabricate BaTiO3/glass nano-composites also in order to retain the nano-grain dielectric properties of BaTiO3 after sintering and enhance the energy storage capacity. Coating layers of low melting glasses of bismuth borosilicate glass (65Bi2O3-20B2O3-15SiO2 mol%) were deposited onto BaTiO3 nanoparticles by a sol precipitation method under ultrasonic agitation. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) results confirmed the formation of core-shell nanostructures with controllable shell thickness between. High densification was achieved by low temperatures (< 900°C) sintering without appreciable grain growth. The bismuth glass coated nano-composite showed high polarization, high dielectric breakdown strength (>1000 kV/cm), suppressed polarization saturation, and low remnant polarization with the energy density of ~ 10 J/cm3 at 1,000 kV/cm.

We have trained 10 undergraduate, 8 Ph.D. and 2 postdoctoral researchers on this project. Basic research experience for undergraduates and graduate students greatly contributed to their professional training, better preparing them for their future careers. The funding associated with this proposal has provided a rigorous research experience for undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs in nano-physics. Students were trained extensively in problem solving while educating themselves on the synthesis and characterization methods common to nano-science. Also the students were involved in the dissemination of their work, both in its presentation at conferences and in the preparation of publications. To summarize, efforts were focused on improving their skills in terms of research, presentations and writing and furthering their abilities as team leaders, i.e. managing and mentoring. Additional efforts were involved in the development a strong  career plan, a competitive job application package, and effective interview skills.
